comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Great detail for a fine building, for me the fire made her more legendary as it otherwise wouldn't have aged gracefully at all. Darling Harbour "Harbourside" comes to mind.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] I tend to agree with you.  Fascinating to see how it was built - a lot like a stage set - no wonder it went up with a 'woof'.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] As seen in this photo www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8005394083/in/pho... it was certainly a light weight structure. This must have been an annex off the main hall as it doesn't have an arched roof and is a bit of a wannabe train shed looking at the roof style. Notice how all the timber trusses have been tarted up with stenciled designs. I had a 13 cm dia. bronze prize medallion for one of the exhibitors a while ago, I think I flogged it on Ebay in a fit of rationalising my belongings.

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Great reference on construction by Peter Proudfoot, Roslyn Maguire and Robert Freestone "Colonial city, global city : Sydney's International Exhibition 1879" trove.nla.gov.au/work/35667688?versionId=45804525 Overlay of the old Garden Palace as it stood in what is now the Sydney Botanic Gardens
